awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Visualizing Emergent Electronic States Near Quantum Phase Transitions
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract:
Unconventional superconductivity is a fascinating state of quantum matter. Its absolute zero resistivity promises the future of clean energy transmission and magnetically-levitated transportation without friction. Superconductivity has been challenging the scientific community for three decades. Unlike in simple metals, where electrons move freely, in unconventional superconductors they are mostly confined in two dimensional planes. This restriction, together with their mutual stronger interaction, create a "traffic jam" of electrons. Externally, altering the number of the electrons leads to various novel states of matter, such as superconductivity and exotic electronic patterns. It remains unclear whether these different electronic states coexist or compete. Using a scanning tunneling microscope, an experimental technique that locally visualizes the electrons, and resonant x-ray scattering, an experimental probe of global electronic states, the research team aims to investigate how these electronic states emerge in various correlated material systems. An important question to be answered is how external tuning can locally destroy one ordered state and enhance another. The project is designed to advance our fundamental understanding of superconductivity and provide means for enhancing their transition temperatures. Educational goals result from this research through outreach activities utilizing the principle investigator's research tools that will amaze and inspire K-12 students with live-demonstrations and hands-on experimentations as well as provide explicit education and training of undergraduate and graduate students.

Technical abstract:
Identifying broken symmetry states near quantum phase transitions remains a key objective of strongly correlated electron systems. A challenging goal is the microscopic understanding of emergent superconductivity. Central to this challenge is the local coexistence of various electronic states, such as nematic, charge, and orbital ordering that preempt, promote, or are intertwined with superconductivity. Probing and visualizing the microscopic origin of these ordered states and deliberately tuning them is the key objective towards understanding and controlling superconductivity. The research program aims to visualize and tune broken symmetry states in d- and f-correlated electron systems near quantum phase transitions. The research team uses a new approach that enables to uniaxially strain these material systems and visualize their response in the electronic density of states through spectroscopic imaging with the scanning tunneling microscope and resonant x-ray scattering. The research program's goal is to discover and understand novel phases of matter in correlated material systems that may promote, enhance, or twist superconductivity. Natural broader impacts result from this research through outreach activities that aim to amaze and inspire K-12 students. Some of these activities involve live demonstrations and hands-on experimentations, such as cryogenic cooling, superconducting levitation and transportation to be performed at the Greater Binghamton Soccer Dome, the Kopernik Observatory & Science Center, and local elementary schools. A graduate level course on experimental techniques in condensed matter is developed by the principle investigator that provides explicit education and training for undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
When bees or ants interact with each other, they form a colony. The colony is a novel complex organization that now exists due to the interaction amongst the entities. In other words, it’s an emergent property that has a novel form of order. Such properties are often difficult to predict. At the quantum level, novel phases of matter emerge from the interaction between a large number of electrons. When electronic interactions are too strong, quantum metals form what is known as Mott insulators, where electrons become localized at each lattice site due to the Coulomb repulsion. Destabilizing (i.e. tuning) this ordered states, leads to unconventional superconductivity, a phenomenon that has been challenging the scientific community for decades. It also drives a number of other electronic orders, such as charge ordering, that is intertwined with superconductivity, ensuing a rich and complex phase diagram. Whether these intertwined phases preempt, promote, or simply coexist with superconductivity is of high importance in identifying its microscopic origin.

The research program is focused on studying strongly correlated quantum materials and search for novel electronically ordered states with the aim of understanding the generic phase diagram of unconventional superconductivity. Using a quantum microscope, known as a scanning tunneling microscope, we probe the quantum states of electrons in different correlated and magnetic quantum materials including 4d-electron ruthenates, 5d-electron iridates and 5f-electron heavy fermions systems. We also investigated correlated magnetic topological materials through the end of the funding period.

We discovered a novel charge-ordered phase, which shares direct  resemblance to the universal charge order in high temperature superconductors. This discovery, with a simultaneous similar finding in another family of quantum materials, makes the charge order ubiquitous phenomenon generally in doped Mott insulators near their destabilization point, regardless whether superconductivity is present or not.

On a parallel front, we broadened these investigations beyond d-electron materials and into f-electron systems. In these materrilas, the f-electrons behave as localized and itinerant (delocalized) at the same time, a phenomenon which has puzzled scientists. Understanding how the same electrons can be localized (leading to magnetism) and delocalized (leading to superconductivity) is crucial question in the mechanism of superconductivity. We discovered that 5f-electrons behave as localized and delocalized depending on their orbital character, a phenomenon termed orbital selectivity. By occupying different flavors of the same f-orbitals, the electrons can either localize and form magnetism or delocalize and become heavy fermions. Such a phenomenon leads to two distinct quantum critical points: one which destabilizes the magnetic order and the another, the Fermi surface. We show that when such a material becomes a ferromagnet, the f-electrons form a large spin-polarized density of states near the Fermi energy leading to what is known as spin-triplet, or spin polarized superconductivity, a phenomenon which is very rare in nature.

Finally, the research program resulted in the investigation of correlated magnetic topological materials, i.e, material that exhibits unique electronic properties due to their topological characteristics. Our objective here is to realize the so called axion insulator state. An axion are not only relevant in the fundamental understanding of topological phenomena, but also have relevance in cosmology.  Furthermore, such materials, if realized, have potential application in quantum computation. We discovered that topological states in a topological antiferromagnet (made of Eu In and As atoms) is actually sensitive to the magnetic ordering. Such a finding indicates that with some material tuning, it will be possible to realize the axion state.

The research program resulted in the support and rigorous training of graduate and undergraduate students in the PI’s laboratory and through organized seminars. The funding also supported outreach activities for K-12 students and the general public through hands on experimentation with superconductivity and cryogenics that took place in local elementary schools. Under this project, the PI also developed a graduate level class on experimental techniques for studying quantum materials, which exposed graduate students to broad range of instrumentation. Finally, the PI wrote an article for the non-scientists about superconductivity, offering the general public and high school students a direct channel to engage with a faculty member.
